prop.head.headtext: Remedies for Breach of Confidential Business Information
Legal Basis for a Claim for Damages

para.paratext: In tort cases such as inducing breach of contract, the general principles regarding the determination of damages in a tort action apply.[1] In Canada there is as of yet no distinct tort action for unfair competition in relation to confidential information.[2] However, in Talbot v. General Television Corporation Pty. Ltd.,[3] the plaintiff, a film producer, developed a television show to depict a series of millionaires and describe how they had made their fortunes. Talbot negotiated with a television network for the sale of his concept. Negotiations were unsuccessful. Later the television company advertised a television series in which millionaires would describe the secrets of their success. The plaintiff sought damages and injunctive relief.
The defendant argued that damages could not be awarded for breach of confidential business information because there was no such tort at common law. However, the court held that:
… I can see no reason, in history or otherwise, why the expression [“wrongful act”] should be given a restricted meaning and I am satisfied that the words are wide enough to cover this case.[4]

See Planon Systems Inc. v. Norman Wade Co. (1998), 82 A.C.W.S. (3d) 403 (Ont. Ct. (Gen. Div.)), where the defendant was liable for loss caused by its tortious conduct, the foreseeable consequence of which was loss of sales to the plaintiff.
MacDonald v. Vapor Canada Ltd. (1976), 66 D.L.R. (3d) 1, [1977] 2 S.C.R. 134. Section 7(e) of the Trade Marks Act, R.S.C. 1970, c. T-10, was ruled ultra vires.
Talbot v. General Television Corporation Pty. Ltd., [1980] V.R. 224.
Talbot v. General Television Corporation Pty. Ltd., [1980] V.R. 224, at p. 241.
